tutorial.title: Mock Database
tutorial.descriptionContent: Use reusable programs to create a Mock Database

executableContent.instructions:
For this project, we'll simulate database queries to understand when certain code blocks run inside a function with the help of conditionals. 

To begin, let's start with a function to get all the users within a database. For this function, the `return` keyword will return all users once the loop is complete.

1. Inside `getAll()`, initialize a variable `allUsers` to an empty array.
2. Create a `for` loop that iterates the length of `userArr`.
3. Push users to `allUsers` on each iteration.
4. Outside and below the for loop, return `allUsers`.

files.name: index.html
files.content:
<!doctype html>
<html>
  <head>
    <link rel="stylesheet" href="./style.css">
  </head>
  <body>
    <form onsubmit="event.preventDefault(); checkExistingUser(event);">
      <label for="name-query">Name Query:</label>
      <input type="text" name="name" placeholder="Enter a name">
      <button type="submit">submit</button>
    </form>
    <form onsubmit="event.preventDefault(); checkLocation(event);">
      <label for="location-query">Location Query:</label>
      <input type="text" name="location" placeholder="Enter a location">
      <button type="submit">submit</button>
    </form>
    <form onsubmit="event.preventDefault(); checkContributions(event);">
      <label for="contributions-query">Contributions Query</label>
      <input type="number" name="contributions" placeholder="Enter an amount">
      <button type="submit">submit</button>
    </form>
    <script src="./script.js"></script>
  </body>
</html>

files.name: style.css
script.js

executableContent.instructions:
Another useful query to a database is to check if there is an existing user. In this function, a conditional will help us run desired instructions to check if a user exists.

1. Inside `checkExistingUser(e)`, create a `for` loop that iterates through the length of `userArr`.
2. Create an `if` statement that checks if the current iteration's name is strictly equal to the form's input value.
3. Log the current iteration's user object if the conditional is satisfied.
4. Return `true`.

files.name: index.html
files.content:
<!doctype html>
<html>
  <head>
    <link rel="stylesheet" href="./style.css">
  </head>
  <body>
    <form onsubmit="event.preventDefault(); checkExistingUser(event);">
      <label for="name-query">Name Query:</label>
      <input type="text" name="name" placeholder="Enter a name">
      <button type="submit">submit</button>
    </form>
    <form onsubmit="event.preventDefault(); checkLocation(event);">
      <label for="location-query">Location Query:</label>
      <input type="text" name="location" placeholder="Enter a location">
      <button type="submit">submit</button>
    </form>
    <form onsubmit="event.preventDefault(); checkContributions(event);">
      <label for="contributions-query">Contributions Query</label>
      <input type="number" name="contributions" placeholder="Enter an amount">
      <button type="submit">submit</button>
    </form>
    <script src="./script.js"></script>
  </body>
</html>

files.name: style.css
script.js

hints.title: Hint
hints.content: Use `e.currentTarget.name.value` to check if the current iteration's name is strictly equal to the form's input value. This syntax gets the value entered into the `input` element (in index.html) when its button is clicked and the event triggers this function.

executableContent.instructions:
Continuing with the `checkExistingUser` function, let's complete the logic by including instructions for when the `if` statement is not satisfied. `checkExistingUser(e)` will still provide meaningful data by returning `false`.

1. Log `"User does not exist"` outside and below the `for` loop.
2. Return `false`.

hints.title: Hint
hints.content: Use `return` to return values. For example, `return val;`.

executableContent.instructions:
The next mock query we'll focus on is checking the last time a user has logged in. A conditional will check if a user hasn't been logged in for a certain amount of days, and the `return` keyword will return any results.

1. Inside `checkLastLogin()`, initialize a variable `results` to an empty array.
2. Create a `for` loop that iterates the length of `userArr`.
3. Use an `if` statement to check if the current user object's last login is `greater than` 10.
4. Push the current user object to the `results` array if the condition is satisfied.
5. Outside and below the for loop, return `results`.

hints.title: Hint
hints.content:
1. Use `return` to return values. Example, `return val;`.
2. To push an element into an array, use `push()`. Example, `array.push(element)`.

executableContent.instructions:
Next, let's create a function that queries the mock database and returns all users from a specific location. In this first part, we'll return the results of our conditionals if they are satisfied.

1. Inside `checkLocation()`, initialize a variable `results` to an empty array. 
2. Use a `for` loop to iterate through the length of `userArr`.
3. Create an `if` statement that checks if the current user object's location is strictly equal to the form's input value.
4. Push the current user object to the `results` array when the conditional is satisfied.
5. Outside and below the for loop, check if the length of `results` is `greater than` 0. 
6. If the above condition is satisfied, then log and return `results`.

files.content:

</html>

hints.title: Hint
hints.content: Use `e.currentTarget.location.value` to check if the current iteration's name is strictly equal to the form's input value.

executableContent.instructions:
To complete the logic for this function, we'll need an `else` statement. When the length of `results` is not greater than 0 and the condition is not satisfied, our else statement will display `"No results found"` and return `false`. 

1. Create the `else` statement's code block.
2. Log `"No results found"`.
3. Return `false`.

hints.title: Hint

executableContent.instructions:
Next, we'll write a function that checks if a user has made a certain amount of contributions. In this first part, we'll return all user objects that satisfy the conditional. We'll use another conditional to check the length of the results array.

1. Inside `checkContributions()`, initialize a variable `validContributions` to an empty array.
2. Create a `for` loop that iterates through the length of `userArr`.
3. Create an `if` statement that checks if the current user object's contributions are `greater than` the form's input value.
4. Push the current user object to `validContributions` when the conditional is satisfied.
5. Outside and below the for loop, check if the length of `validContributions` is `greater than` 0.
6. If the above condition is satisfied, log and return `validContributions`.

</html>

hints.content: Use `e.currentTarget.contributions.value` to check if the current user object's contributions are `greater than` the form's input value.

To complete this function, we'll need an `else` statement for when the length of `validContributions` does not satisfy the conditional.

1. Create the `else` statement's code block.
2. Log `"No results found"`.
3. Return `false`.

hints.title: Hint

executableContent.instructions:
Lastly, let's take a look at a function that deletes a user from the database. We'll use the `return` keyword to return `true` if a user is successfully removed.

1. Create a `for` loop that iterates through the length of `userArr`.
2. Check if the current user object's name is strictly equal to `"Selene"`.
3. `splice` with the index of the current user object and remove the object when the conditional is satisfied.
4. Log `"User deleted successfully", userArr`.
5.  Return `true`.
6. Log `"User not found"` outside and below the for-loop.

files.content:

  <head>

  </head>
  <body>

      <label for="name-query">Name Query:</label>
      <input type="text" name="name" placeholder="Enter a name">
      <button type="submit">submit</button>
    </form>
    <form onsubmit="event.preventDefault(); checkLocation(event);">
      <label for="location-query">Location Query:</label>
      <input type="text" name="location" placeholder="Enter a location">
      <button type="submit">submit</button>
    </form>
    <form onsubmit="event.preventDefault(); checkContributions(event);">
      <label for="contributions-query">Contributions Query</label>
      <input type="number" name="contributions" placeholder="Enter an amount">
      <button type="submit">submit</button>
    </form>
    <script src="./script.js"></script>
  </body>
</html>

hints.title: Hint
hints.content: `.splice()` expects two arguments - a starting index and the number of items to remove. In this lesson, remove only one.
